did.abstract: Edward V. Olencki was a practicing architect and a professor at the University of Michigan College of Architecture and Urban Planning from 1949 to 1987. Prior to coming to Ann Arbor, Olencki worked as a designer and draftsman for prominent architect Mies van der Rohe while studying at the Illinois Institute of Technology.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: This collection was donated by Mrs. Irene Olencki (Donor 9271) in November 2002.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open without restriction.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Edward V. Olencki Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Edward Olencki attended the Illinois Institute of Technology (IIT.), where he earned a BS in architecture in 1944 and an MS in 1949. During his time at IIT, he worked as a draftsman and designer in the offices of famed architect, Mies van der Rohe in Chicago from 1943 to 1948. In 1948, Olencki left Chicago to take a position at the University of Michigan as an instructor. He was promoted to assistant professor in 1950, associate professor in 1953, and full professor in 1963. Olencki primarily taught courses on construction materials and methods, comprehensive architectural design, and furniture design. His research interests focused on modern church architecture, and he completed two sabbaticals in Europe studying this theme. During his time at Michigan Olencki also ran his own architectural firm, designing homes, churches, and commercial buildings.

In 2000 Olencki saluted his former mentor and employer, Mies van der Rohe, by donating a collection of over 200 of Mies van der Rohe's architectural drawings to the University of Michigan. These drawings were exhibited as "Mies in Michigan."

When he retired in 1987, Olencki was named Professor Emeritus of Architecture in honor of his years as an excellent and devoted teacher (See Proceedings of the Board of Regents, June 1987). Olencki died on March 14, 2002 at the age of 79.

scopecontent.p: This collection primarily reflects Olencki's work as a practicing architect, but also contains some materials related to his research interest in church design, and his association with Mies van der Rohe.

scopecontent.p: The series Illinois Institute of Technology, 1949-1950, consists of Olencki's 1949 Masters thesis paper on church design, including photographs of his church model.

did.unittitle: Masters Thesis, "The Small Catholic Church: Problem and Proposed Solution," 1950

scopecontent.p: The Architectural Plans, 1946-1993 series is the largest part of the collection and contains architectural drawings and blueprints, letters, and proposals. The series contains three files on Mies van der Rohe buildings (technology center at Illinois Institute of Technology, and Algonquin Apartments and Lakeview Apartments). The series is divided by type of structure: residential, commercial, church, or academic. Residential architecture includes the home built for fellow architecture professor Leonard K. Eaton. Church architecture includes an addition to St. Mary's Student Chapel In Ann Arbor, and Divine Savior Church in Westland.

did.unittitle: Various Sketches of New House Plans, 1953
Algonquin Apartments, Mies van der Rohe, Architect
Lakeview Apartments, Mies van der Rohe, Architect
Magee Residence, Isle of Capri, Florida, 1985
Amsters Residence Remodel, Ann Arbor, MI, 1993
Gabriel Richard Center, Ann Arbor, MI, 1963 1979
St. Mary's Student Chapel, Ann Arbor, MI, 1966
New Technology Center for the Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, Illinois, Mies van der Rohe, Architect, 1946

scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous, ca. 1960-1971, series contains church sketches and furniture designs, notes and letters from Olencki's sabbaticals, and greeting cards from Mies van der Rohe.

did.unittitle: Greeting Cards from Mies van der Rohe

scopecontent.p: The Photographs, ca. 1940s-1970s series contains photos of building exteriors from Olencki's time with Mies van der Rohe as well as photos of Taliesin, Frank Lloyd Wright's home and workspace in Spring Green, Wisconsin.

did.unittitle: Building Exteriors from time at the offices of Mies van der Rohe (includes photographs of Olencki with Mies)
Taliesin (by Frank Lloyd Wright) and exterior photos of Frank Lloyd Wright-designed office building
